newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Five jailed for part in Swedish neo-Nazi rally.
newsitem.headline: Five jailed for part in Swedish neo-Nazi rally.

text.p: Five Swedish neo-Nazis were jailed by a court on Monday for inciting racial hatred when they took part in a ceremony to commemorate the death of Adolf Hitler's deputy, Rudolf Hess.
The five, sentenced to two months' imprisonment each, were arrested in August at the ceremony in Trollhattan, in southern Sweden, which ended in clashes between neo-Nazis and anti-racist groups.
Two others arrested at the same time were given suspended sentences because they were under 18.
All of them were members of the right-wing National Socialist Front.
The leader of the group made a speech praising Hess from a makeshift stage at the ceremony which was attended by hundreds of neo-Nazis from all over Sweden, Denmark, Britain and Germany.

Hess, who died in Berlin's Spandau prison in 1987 aged 93, has become a hero of the neo-Nazi movement across Europe. The anniversary of his death been made a rallying point for the radical right in Germany and other countries.

The Trollhattan demonstration was eventually broken up by about 600 police, some on horseback, after fighting broke out between the neo-Nazis and anti-racists who had also travelled from several countries.
